These experiments demonstrate that simple kernel methods combined with scalable algorithms based on accelerated RPCholesky can be competitive for problems in scientific machine learning.
4. Theoretical results. This section compares accelerated RPCholesky with simple RPCholesky using rigorous error analysis. On the surface, the comparison is straightforward. Since accelerated RPCholesky generates the same distribution of pivots as simple RPCholesky, it satisfies the main RPCholesky error bound [4, Thm. 5.1]:

Theorem 4.1 (Sufficient pivots for simple and accelerated RPCholesky [4]). Consider a psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$, and let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(k)}$ denote the random residual after applying simple or accelerated RPCholesky with $k$ random pivots. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(k)}\right)\right] \leq(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})
$$

as soon as

$$
k \geq \frac{r}{\varepsilon}+r \log \left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon \eta}\right), \quad \text { where } \eta=\frac{\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}{\sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}
$$

Theorem 4.1 bounds the sufficient number of pivots in accelerated RPCholesky, yet it does not bound the sufficient number of iterations needed to produce the pivots via rejection sampling. The following new result completes the theoretical understanding of accelerated RPCholesky, by bounding the number of iterations. It also provides error bounds for block RPCholesky. This new result will be proved in subsections 4.3 to 4.6 .

THEOREM 4.2 (Sufficient iterations for accelerated and block RPCholesky). Consider a psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$, and let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}$ denote the random residual after applying $t$ rounds of accelerated RPCholesky or block RPCholesky with a block size $b \geq 1$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right)\right] \leq(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})
$$

as soon as the number of proposed pivots bt satisfies

$$
b t \geq \frac{r}{\varepsilon}+(r+b) \log \left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon \eta}\right), \quad \text { where } \eta=\frac{\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}{\sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}
$$

The comparison between accelerated and block RPCholesky follows from a coupling argument in which block RPCholesky accepts a greater number of pivots than accelerated RPCholesky in each round, leading to a higher approximation quality. However, in this comparison, accelerated RPCholesky has the benefit of rejecting many of the proposed pivots and therefore producing a similarly accurate approximation with a smaller approximation rank. When the methods are run with the same approximation rank, accelerated RPCholesky can be much more accurate, as reflected in the numerical experiments of section 3 and especially the failure modes of block RPCholesky in Figures 2 and 3.

The bounds in Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 hold for all accuracy levels $\varepsilon>0$, and they each contain a term $r / \varepsilon$, which is the minimal number of pivots needed to guarantee an error level $(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})$ in any low-rank approximation produced by a pivoted partial Cholesky decomposition applied to a worst-case matrix [4, Thm. C.1]. The bounds also contain a term $r \log (1 /(\varepsilon \eta))$ or $(r+b) \log (1 /(\varepsilon \eta))$, which represents the number of pivots that need to be accepted or proposed for the algorithm to improve the approximation quality from an initial error level $\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})=\eta^{-1} \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})$ to a lower error level $(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})$. Indeed, the only difference between Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 is the quantity $b \log (1 /(\varepsilon \eta))$, present in the latter. This difference becomes significant when the theorems are evaluated for a small target rank $r<b$ and a tiny approximation error $\eta \ll 1$. This extreme setting occurs when the matrix $\boldsymbol{A}$ is nearly rank- $r$. Then, accelerated RPCholesky accepts very few proposals per round, so it takes many rounds to converge to high accuracy.

Last, Theorem 4.2 can be compared with the bound of Deshpande, Rademacher, Vempala, and Wang [9]. Their bound was originally derived for block randomly pivoted QR, but it can be extended to block RPCholesky. Here is a simplified version of their result, adapted from [4, sec. 3.6]:

THEOREM 4.3 (Sufficient iterations for block RPCholesKy with a large block size [9]). Fix $\varepsilon \leq 3 / 2$ and a large block size $b \geq 3 r / \varepsilon$. Consider a psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A}$, and let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}$ denote the random residual after applying $t$ rounds of block RPCholesky. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right)\right] \leq(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})
$$

as soon as

$$
t \geq 1+\frac{\log (1 / \eta+1)}{\log (3 / \varepsilon)}, \quad \text { where } \eta=\frac{\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}{\sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})}
$$

When Theorems 4.2 and 4.3 are both applicable, they specify a similar number of sufficient iterations for block RPCholesky to converge to high accuracy. However, Theorem 4.3 has a more limited range of applicability since it requires a large block size $b \geq 3 r / \varepsilon$. This prescription for a large block size is exactly the reverse of block RPCholesky's behavior in practice, in which the method provides more accurate approximations given a smaller block size. In particular, Theorem 4.3 has limited applicability in the typical setting where the user tunes the block size $b$ for a given computing setup to achieve the fastest runtime. The final weakness of Theorem 4.3 is that it does not extend to accelerated RPCholesky.
4.1. Method of proof. The proof uses many probabilistic and linear algebraic tools that were introduced in the analysis of simple RPCholesky [4, Thm. 5.1], and it follows the same core approach:
(a) Evaluate the function that gives the expected value of the residual matrix after generating and processing a single pivot.
(b) Prove monotonicity and concavity properties for the expected residual function.
(c) Use monotonicity and concavity to identify a worst-case matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times N}$.
(d) Analyze the worst-case matrix to produce error bounds.

As the core difficulty, accelerated RPCholesky leads to an expected residual function that does not satisfy the matrix monotonicity property. Therefore, it is necessary to develop more subtle concavity and monotonicity properties and the proof is twice as long as before.

The expected residual function for accelerated RPCholesky can be derived as follows. Let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, i)}$ be the low-rank approximation generated from the first $i \leq b$ proposals, and let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}=\boldsymbol{A}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, i)}$ be the corresponding residual matrix. Accelerated RPCholesky updates the residual matrix in three steps:

1. A pivot $s_{i+1}^{\prime}$ is sampled according to $\mathbb{P}\left\{s_{i+1}^{\prime}=j\right\}=\boldsymbol{A}(j, j) / \operatorname{tr} \boldsymbol{A}$.
2. The pivot is accepted with probability $\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j, j) / \boldsymbol{A}(j, j)$.
3. Conditional on acceptance, the residual matrix is updated:

$$
\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i+1)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}-\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(:, j) \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j,:) / \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j, j)
$$

By combining steps 1-3 above, the expected residual matrix is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i+1)} \mid \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}\right] & =\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}-\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\boldsymbol{A}(j, j)}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})} \cdot \frac{\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j, j)}{\boldsymbol{A}(j, j)} \cdot \frac{\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(:, j) \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j,:)}{\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}(j, j)} \\
& =\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the expected residual function can be defined as:

$$
\phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{1}{\alpha} x^{2}, \quad \text { where } \alpha=\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A}) \text { and } x=\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, i)}
$$

This function depends on a scalar parameter $\alpha>0$, and it can be evaluated for inputs $x$ that are scalars or matrices. By repeated function composition, this function bounds the expected residual matrix of accelerated RPCholesky after any number of steps.

Bounding the error in this way requires an expected residual function that is concave and monotone. However, the function $\phi_{\alpha}(x)$ barely has enough monotonocity for the argument to work. In particular, the mapping $x \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}(x)$ is only monotone for scalars $x \in[0, \alpha / 2]$, and it fails to be monotone for large classes of psd matrices.

The analysis pushes through the technical difficulties and produces an upper bound for accelerated RPCholesky depending on the expected residual function. The bound becomes worse when the eigenvalues are averaged together or increased. Hence, the worst-case matrix takes the form

$$
\boldsymbol{A}=\operatorname{diag}\left\{\underbrace{\gamma}_{\boldsymbol{r}, \ldots, \underbrace{r}_{r} \underbrace{\gamma}_{r}} \underbrace{\beta}_{\begin{array}{c}
N-r \\
N-r \text { times }
\end{array}}, \underbrace{\beta}_{\begin{array}{c}
N-r \\
N-r \text { times }
\end{array}},\right\}, \quad \text { where } \begin{cases}\gamma=\sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A}), \\ \beta=\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A}) .\end{cases}
$$

It is a two-cluster matrix with a small block of leading eigenvalues and a large block of trailing eigenvalues. The identification of this two-cluster matrix is not new: the same worst-case matrix was already encountered in the proof of [4, Thm. 5.1]. Applying the expected residual function to this matrix completes the proof of Theorem 4.2.
4.2. Organization of proof. Here is the overall organization for the proof of Theorem 4.2, which will be carried out over the next four subsections.

Part I: Properties of the expected residual function. The first part of the analysis (subsection 4.3) establishes concavity and monotonicity properties for the expected residual function. The concavity and monotonicity properties are more detailed than what was proved in [4, Thm. 5.1].

Part II: Accelerated RPCholesky error. The second part of the analysis (subsection 4.4) establishes the following error bound:

Lemma 4.4 (Central error bound). Fix a block size $b \geq 1$ and a target psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$. Let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}$ denote the residual matrix after applying $t$ rounds of accelerated or block RPCholesky with blocks of $b$ proposals. Also introduce the matrix-valued function

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\boldsymbol{M})=\underbrace{\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})} \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})}}_{b \text { times }}(\boldsymbol{M}), \quad \text { where } \quad \phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{1}{\alpha} x^{2}
$$

and let $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}=\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b} \circ \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b} \circ \cdots \circ \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ denote the $t$-fold composition of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$. Then, the eigenvalues of $\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right]$ are bounded by the eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{A})$ as follows:

$$
\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right]\right) \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{A})\right) \quad \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, N
$$

The proof of Lemma 4.4 is the most intricate argument of the paper. This lemma shows that the expected trace norm error is bounded by a deterministic quantity:

$$
\mathbb{E} \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right) \leq \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{A})\right)
$$

This upper bound depends only on the eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{A}$, independent of the eigenvectors.

Part III: Permutation averaging lemma. The next key idea is to average together the leading eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{A}$ and also average together the trailing eigenvalues. Subsection 4.5 proves the following helpful lemma, which shows that the averaging can only make the error worse:

Lemma 4.5 (Permutation averaging). For any diagonal, psd matrix $\boldsymbol{\Lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times N}$ and any random permutation $\boldsymbol{P} \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times N}$,

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right) \leq \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right]\right)\right)
$$

Part IV: Main error bound. The last part of the analysis in subsection 4.6 examines the worst-case matrix $\boldsymbol{A}$ and obtains a simple recursive formula for $\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{A})\right)$ in terms of $t$. Bounding the recursion leads to the proof of the main result, Theorem 4.2.
4.3. Part I: Properties of the expected residual function. This section establishes concavity and monotonicity properties for the expected residual function. The first lemma considers the application of this function to scalars:

Lemma 4.6 (Expected residual properties). Let $\phi_{\alpha}:[0, \alpha] \rightarrow[0, \alpha]$ be the function $\phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{1}{\alpha} x^{2}$, and let

$$
\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}=\underbrace{\phi_{\alpha} \circ \phi_{\alpha} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{\alpha}}_{b \text { times }}
$$

denote the $b$-fold composition of $\phi_{\alpha}$. Then the following holds for each $b \geq 1$ :
(a) Uniform boundedness: $\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)} \leq \alpha / 4$.
(b) Monotonicity in $x$ on $[0, \alpha / 2]: \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x) \leq \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ if $x \leq x^{\prime} \leq \alpha / 2$.
(c) Joint positive homogeneity: $\phi_{\beta \cdot \alpha}^{(b)}(\beta \cdot x)=\beta \cdot \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)$ for $\beta>0$.
(d) Joint concavity: The mapping $(x, \alpha) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)$ is concave:

$$
\theta \phi_{\alpha_{1}}^{(b)}\left(x_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \phi_{\alpha_{2}}^{(b)}\left(x_{2}\right) \leq \phi_{\theta \alpha_{1}+(1-\theta) \alpha_{2}}^{(b)}\left(\theta x_{1}+(1-\theta) x_{2}\right) \quad \text { for } \quad \theta \in(0,1)
$$

(e) Upper bound: $\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x) \leq 1 /\left(b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}\right)$.

Proof. See Appendix B.
The next lemma shows that the expected residual function continues to exhibit concavity and monotonicity when it is applied to certain classes of matrices.

Lemma 4.7 (Expected residual properties for matrices). Define

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\boldsymbol{A})=\underbrace{\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})} \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}}_{b \text { times }}(\boldsymbol{A}), \quad \text { where } \quad \phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{1}{\alpha} x^{2}
$$

Let $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}=\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b} \circ \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b} \circ \cdots \circ \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ denote the $t$-fold composition of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$. Then the following holds for any $t \geq 1$ :
(a) $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}$ is non-decreasing on the space of diagonal, psd matrices:

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) \quad \text { if } \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1} \preceq \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}
$$

(b) $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}$ is concave on the space of diagonal, psd matrices:

$$
\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) \quad \text { for } \theta \in(0,1)
$$

(c) $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}$ is concave on the space of all psd matrices:

$$
\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{A}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right) \quad \text { for } \theta \in(0,1)
$$

Proof. See Appendix B.
4.4. Part II: Accelerated RPCholesky error. This section analyzes the error of accelerated RPCholesky and proves Lemma 4.4. The technical crux is the following proposition, which bounds the error of accelerated RPCholesky or block RPCholesky applied to a random psd matrix.

Proposition 4.8 (Block and accelerated RPCholesky on a random matrix). Consider a random psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$, and let $\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}$ denote the residual matrix after applying one round of accelerated RPCholesky or block RPCholesky to $\boldsymbol{A}$ with $b \geq 1$ proposals. Also introduce the matrix-valued function

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\boldsymbol{M})=\underbrace{\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})} \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})} \circ \cdots \circ \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{M})}}_{b \text { times }}(\boldsymbol{M}), \quad \text { where } \quad \phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{1}{\alpha} x^{2}
$$

Then the eigenvalues of $\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right]$ are bounded by the eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(1, b)}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])$ :

$$
\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right]\right) \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right) \quad \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, N
$$

The proof of this result relies on the min-max principle [37, Thm. 8.9]:
Lemma 4.9 (Min-max principle). The eigenvalues of a Hermitian matrix $\boldsymbol{M} \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$ satisfy

$$
\lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{M})=\min _{\operatorname{dim}(\mathcal{S})=N-i+1} \max _{\boldsymbol{v} \in \mathcal{S},\|\boldsymbol{v}\|=1} \boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{M} \boldsymbol{v}
$$

where the maximum is taken over all $(N-i+1)$-dimensional linear subspaces $\mathcal{S}$. The optimal $\mathcal{S}$ is spanned by the eigenvectors of $\boldsymbol{M}$ with the $N-i+1$ smallest eigenvalues.

Proof of Proposition 4.8. The proof has three steps.
Step 1: Comparison of block and accelerated RPCholesky. Accelerated RPCholesky and block RPCholesky yield the same distribution of pivot proposals, so the proposals $\mathrm{S}^{\prime}=\left\{s_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, s_{b}^{\prime}\right\}$ are assumed to be identical. Block RPCholESKY then accepts all the proposals, leading to a residual matrix

$$
\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, b)}=\boldsymbol{A}-\boldsymbol{A}\left(:, \mathrm{S}^{\prime}\right) \boldsymbol{A}\left(\mathrm{S}^{\prime}, \mathrm{S}^{\prime}\right)^{\dagger} \boldsymbol{A}\left(\mathrm{S}^{\prime},:\right)=\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}^{\prime}\right)}\right) \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}
$$

where

$$
\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}^{\prime}\right)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}^{\prime}\right) \boldsymbol{A}\left(\mathrm{S}^{\prime}, \mathrm{S}^{\prime}\right)^{\dagger} \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathrm{~S}^{\prime},:\right)
$$

is the orthogonal projection onto the range of $\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}^{\prime}\right)$. In contrast, accelerated RPCholesky accepts a subset of the proposals $\mathrm{S} \subseteq \mathrm{S}^{\prime}$, leading to a residual matrix

$$
\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}(:, \mathrm{~S})}\right) \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}
$$

The range of $\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathbb{S}^{\prime}\right)$ is no smaller than the range of $\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}(:, \mathbb{S})$, so

$$
\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathbb{S}^{\prime}\right)} \preceq \mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}(:, \mathbb{S})}
$$

Conjugate both sides of (4.1) with $\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}$ to yield

$$
\widetilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, b)}=\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(:, \mathbb{S}^{\prime}\right)}\right) \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2} \preceq \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}(:, \mathbb{S})}\right) \boldsymbol{A}^{1 / 2}=\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}
$$

Taking expectations, it follows that $\mathbb{E}\left[\widetilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, b)}\right] \preceq \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right]$ and, by Weyl's inequality,

$$
\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\widetilde{\boldsymbol{A}}^{(1, b)}\right]\right) \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right]\right), \quad \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, N
$$

This completes the comparison of block and accelerated RPCholesky.
Step 2: Bounding $\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v}$. Now it suffices to analyze the accelerated RPCholesky error. This proof will do so by (a) deriving an upper bound for the quadratic form $\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v}$, (b) constructing a $(N-i+1)$-dimensional subspace where the Rayleigh quotients are no larger than $\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{k}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)$, and (c) invoking the min-max principle.

The residual for accelerated RPCholesky after the first proposal has expectation

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})} \boldsymbol{A}^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\boldsymbol{A})\right]
$$

Since $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}$ is concave over psd matrices (Lemma 4.7c), Jensen's inequality implies

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\boldsymbol{A})\right] \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])
$$

Next fix a unit-length vector $\boldsymbol{v} \in \mathbb{C}^{N}$ and conjugate both sides of this display with $\boldsymbol{v}$ :

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \boldsymbol{v}\right] \leq \boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}]) \boldsymbol{v}
$$

By boundedness of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}$ and monotonicity of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}$ (Lemma 4.6a-b), it follows

$$
\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \boldsymbol{v}\right]\right) \leq \phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}]) \boldsymbol{v}\right)
$$

The residual matrix after the $(\ell+1)$ st proposal has conditional expectation

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell+1)} \mid \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)}, \boldsymbol{A}\right]=\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)}\right)^{2}
$$

Conjugate both sides of this display with $\boldsymbol{v}$ to obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell+1)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)}, \boldsymbol{A}\right] & =\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})} \boldsymbol{v}^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)}\right)^{2} \boldsymbol{v} \\
& \leq \boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v}-\frac{1}{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v}\right)^{2}=\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality follows because $\boldsymbol{v} \boldsymbol{v}^{*}$ is a contraction. Take expectations and apply Jensen's inequality to the concave function $x \mapsto \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}(x)$ (Lemma 4.6d):

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell+1)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v}\right) \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right] \leq \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right)
$$

Use the boundedness of $\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}$ and monotonicity of $\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}^{(b-\ell-1)}$ (Lemma 4.6a-b) to show

$$
\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}^{(b-\ell-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell+1)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right) \leq \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}^{(b-\ell)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, \ell)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right)
$$

Chaining the above inequalities for $\ell=1,2, \ldots, b-1$ yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right] \leq \phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}^{(b-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right)
$$

Taking expectations yields:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v} & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\phi_{\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})}^{(b-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \boldsymbol{v} \mid \boldsymbol{A}\right]\right)\right] \\
& \leq \phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{A}^{(1,1)} \boldsymbol{v}\right]\right) \leq \phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}]) \boldsymbol{v}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The second inequality is Jensen's inequality applied to the jointly concave function $(x, \alpha) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}^{(b-1)}(x)$ (Lemma 4.6d), and the third inequality is (4.2). This establishes a convenient upper bound for the quadratic form $\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v}$.

Step 3: Apply the min-max principle. Let $\boldsymbol{v}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{v}_{N}$ be eigenvectors of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])$, associated with its decreasingly ordered eigenvalues. For any unit-length vector $\boldsymbol{v} \in \operatorname{span}\left\{\boldsymbol{v}_{i}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{v}_{N}\right\}$, the min-max variational principle implies

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}]) \boldsymbol{v} \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)
$$

By (4.3), boundedness of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[(\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}$, and monotonicity of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[(\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}$ (Lemma 4.6a-b), it follows

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v} \leq \phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}]) \boldsymbol{v}\right) \leq \phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)\right)
$$

By boundedness of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[(\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}$ and the monotonicity of $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}$ (Lemma 4.6a-b), the matrices $\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])$ have the same eigenvectors with the same ordering of the eigenvalues. Hence,

$$
\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)\right)=\lambda_{i}\left(\phi_{\mathbb{E}[\operatorname{tr}(\boldsymbol{A})]}^{(b-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)\right)=\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)
$$

Combining the two previous displays yields

$$
\boldsymbol{v}^{*} \mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right] \boldsymbol{v} \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right) \quad \text { for any unit-length } \boldsymbol{v} \in \operatorname{span}\left\{\boldsymbol{v}_{i}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{v}_{N}\right\}
$$

It follows from the min-max variational principle that $\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(1, b)}\right]\right) \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{A}])\right)$, completing the proof.

The central result of this section is proved by iteratively applying Proposition 4.8.
Proof of Lemma 4.4. The $(s+1)$ st round of accelerated RPCholesky or block RPCholesky leads to the same residual matrix as a single round of accelerated RPCholesky or block RPCholesky applied to the psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}$. Thus, Proposition 4.8 shows that

$$
\lambda_{i}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s+1)}\right]\right) \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}\right]\right)\right) \quad \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, N
$$

Next take eigendecompositions

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s+1)}\right]=\boldsymbol{Q}_{1} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1} \boldsymbol{Q}_{1}^{*} \quad \text { and } \quad \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}\right]\right)=\boldsymbol{Q}_{2} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2} \boldsymbol{Q}_{2}^{*}
$$

where the eigenvalues are listed in weakly decreasing order. Equation (4.4) implies $\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1} \preceq \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}$, so the monotonicity of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}$ (Lemma 4.7a) further implies

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)
$$

The function $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ is covariant under unitary basis transformations:

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{Q}^{*}\right)=\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}) \boldsymbol{Q}^{*} \quad \text { for unitary } \boldsymbol{Q} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}
$$

Therefore, the eigenvalue ordering (4.5) implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{Q}_{i}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s+1)}\right]\right) \boldsymbol{Q}_{1} & =\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) \\
& \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)=\boldsymbol{Q}_{2}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}\right]\right) \boldsymbol{Q}_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the eigenvalues are invariant under unitary basis transformations, Weyl's inequality implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s+1)}\right]\right)\right) & =\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}_{i}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s-1)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s+1)}\right]\right) \boldsymbol{Q}_{1}\right) \\
& \leq \lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}_{2}^{*} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{i}^{(t-s)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}\right]\right) \boldsymbol{Q}_{2}\right)=\lambda_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t-s)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{A}^{(s)}\right]\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Apply (4.6) for $s=0,1, \ldots, t-1$ to complete the proof.
4.5. Part III: Permutation averaging lemma. The permutation averaging lemma has the following short and simple proof.

Proof of Lemma 4.5. Since the trace is invariant under permutations and the function $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ is covariant under permutations,

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}) \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right)\right)
$$

Now apply Jensen's inequality to the concave function $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}$ (Lemma 4.7b):

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right)\right] \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right]\right)
$$

Since the trace respects the psd ordering, it follows

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right)\right]\right) \leq \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right]\right)\right)
$$

This completes the proof.
4.6. Part IV: Main error bound. At this point, the main error bound for accelerated RPCholesky is nearly in hand. The last step is an analysis argument that explicitly bounds the error for a worst-case instance of accelerated RPCholesky.

Proof of Theorem 4.2. Take an eigendecomposition $\boldsymbol{A}=\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{Q}^{*}$. By Lemma 4.4,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\right)\right] \leq \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{A})\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{Q}^{*}\right)\right)
$$

Since the trace is invariant under unitary basis transformations and the function $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ is covariant under unitary basis transformations,

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{Q}^{*}\right)\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}) \boldsymbol{Q}^{*}\right)=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right)
$$

Therefore, the upper bound only depends on the eigenvalue matrix $\boldsymbol{\Lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times N}$.
Next, take a random permutation $\boldsymbol{P}$ that permutes the first $r$ coordinates uniformly at random and permutes the trailing $N-r$ coordinates uniformly at random. By Lemma 4.5,

$$
\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right) \leq \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\widetilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}})\right), \quad \text { where } \widetilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}=\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{\Lambda} \boldsymbol{P}^{*}\right]
$$

The matrix $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}$ has the explicit form

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}=\operatorname{diag}\left\{\underbrace{\frac{\alpha}{r}, \ldots, \frac{\alpha}{r}}_{r \text { times }}, \underbrace{\frac{\beta}{N-r}, \ldots, \frac{\beta}{N-r}}_{N-r \text { times }},\right\}, \quad \text { where }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{r} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A}) \\
\beta=\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{A})
\end{array}\right.
$$

It is a two-cluster matrix that leads to the worst possible value of $\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{\Lambda})\right)$
For the next step, argue by induction that

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}) \preceq \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{(t)}, \quad \text { where } \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{(t)}=\operatorname{diag}\left\{\underbrace{\frac{\alpha^{(t)}}{r}, \ldots, \frac{\alpha^{(t)}}{r}}_{r \text { times }}, \underbrace{\frac{\beta}{N-r}, \ldots, \frac{\beta}{N-r}}_{N-r \text { times }}\right\}
$$

and the entries $\alpha^{(t)}$ are given by the recursion

$$
\alpha^{(t+1)}=\alpha^{(t)}-\frac{b\left(\alpha^{(t)}\right)^{2}}{(b+r) \alpha^{(t)}+r \beta}, \quad \alpha^{(0)}=\alpha
$$

The comparison (4.7) is valid with equality at time $t=0$. Assume the comparison is valid at a time $t \geq 0$. Using the monotonicity of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$ (Lemma 4.7a) it follows that

$$
\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t+1)}(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{(t)}\right)=\phi_{\alpha^{(t)}+\beta}^{(b)}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{(t)}\right)
$$

By Lemma 4.6e, the trailing $N-r$ diagonal entries of $\phi_{\alpha^{(t)}+\beta}^{(b)}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{(t)}\right)$ are bounded by $\frac{\beta}{N-r}$ and the leading $r$ diagonal entries are bounded by

$$
\frac{1}{\frac{b}{\alpha^{(t)}+\beta}+\frac{r}{\alpha^{(t)}}}=\frac{1}{r}\left[\alpha^{(t)}-\frac{b\left(\alpha^{(t)}\right)^{2}}{(b+r) \alpha^{(t)}+r \beta}\right]
$$

Therefore, (4.7) holds for all $t \geq 0$ by induction.
At each instant $t=0,1, \ldots$, the discrete-time dynamical system $\alpha^{(t)}$ (4.8) is bounded from above by a continuous-time dynamical system $\alpha(t)$ that satisfies

$$
\dot{\alpha}(t)=-\frac{b(\alpha(t))^{2}}{(b+r) \alpha(t)+r \beta}, \quad \alpha^{(0)}=\alpha
$$

The comparison holds because $x \mapsto b x^{2} /((b+r) x+r \beta)$ is a non-negative, nondecreasing function.

Last, assume that $\alpha \leq \varepsilon \beta$. (Otherwise, the theorem holds trivially at all times $t \geq$ 0.) By separation of variables, the continuous-time dynamical system (4.9) satisfies $\alpha(t) \leq \varepsilon \beta$ as soon as

$$
t=\left[-\frac{b+r}{b} \log (\alpha(t))+\frac{r \beta}{b} \alpha(t)^{-1}\right]_{\alpha(0)=\alpha}^{\alpha(t)=\varepsilon \beta}=\frac{b+r}{b} \log \left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon \eta}\right)+\frac{r}{b \varepsilon}-\frac{r}{b} \eta
$$

This establishes a slightly stronger version of the theorem, completing the proof.
5. Extension: Accelerated randomly pivoted QR. The pivoted partial Cholesky decomposition of a psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A}$ is closely related to the pivoted partial QR decomposition of a general, possibly rectangular, matrix $\boldsymbol{B} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times N}$. This section reviews the connection betweeen algorithms and introduces a new accelerated randomly pivoted $Q R$ algorithm for general low-rank matrix approximation.

Algorithm 5.1 Randomly pivoted QR
Input: Matrix $\boldsymbol{B} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times N}$; approximation rank $k$
Output: Matrices $\boldsymbol{Q} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times k}, \boldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times k}$ defining $\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}=\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{F}^{*}$; pivot set S
Initialize $\boldsymbol{Q} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{M \times k}, \boldsymbol{F} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{N \times k}, \mathrm{~S} \leftarrow \emptyset$, and $\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \operatorname{SquaredColumnNorms}(\boldsymbol{B})$ for $i=1$ to $k$ do

Sample pivot $s \sim \boldsymbol{d} / \sum_{j} d_{j}$
Induct new pivot $\mathrm{S} \leftarrow \mathrm{S} \cup\{s\}$
$\boldsymbol{g} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{B}(:, s)-\boldsymbol{Q}(:, 1: 1-i) \boldsymbol{F}(s, 1: i-1)^{*}$
$\boldsymbol{Q}(:, i) \leftarrow \boldsymbol{g} /\|\boldsymbol{g}\|$
$\boldsymbol{F}(:, i) \leftarrow \boldsymbol{B}^{*} \boldsymbol{Q}(:, i)$
$\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{d}-|\boldsymbol{F}(:, i)|^{2}$
end for

A low-rank approximation for a general matrix can be computed by columnpivoted QR as follows: Begin by initializing the approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}^{(0)} \vDash \mathbf{0}$ and the residual $\boldsymbol{B}^{(0)}:=\boldsymbol{B}$. For each $i=0, \ldots, k-1$, perform the following steps:

1. Select a pivot column. Choose $s_{i+1} \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$.
2. Update. Evaluate the column $\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right)$ indexed by the pivot index $s_{i+1}$. Update the approximation and the residual:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}^{(i+1)} & :=\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}^{(i)}+\frac{\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right) \boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right)^{*} \boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}}{\left\|\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right)\right\|^{2}} \\
\boldsymbol{B}^{(i+1)} & :=\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}-\frac{\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right) \boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right)^{*} \boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}}{\left\|\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}\left(:, s_{i+1}\right)\right\|^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Each update has the effect of orthogonalizing the residual $\boldsymbol{B}^{(i)}$ against the column indexed by the selected pivot and adjusting the approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}^{(i)}$ accordingly. This version of column-pivoted QR has issues with numerically stability and is provided for conceptual understanding only. Numerically stable implementation of QR decomposition methods is discussed in numerical linear algebra textbooks, e.g., [20, ch. 5].

Pivoted QR and Cholesky approximations are closely related (see, e.g., [21]):
Proposition 5.1 (QR and Cholesky). Suppose that column-pivoted QR is executed on a matrix $\boldsymbol{B}$ with pivots $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{k}$ producing an approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}} \approx \boldsymbol{B}$. Similarly, suppose that partial Cholesky is performed on the Gram matrix $\boldsymbol{A}:=\boldsymbol{B}^{*} \boldsymbol{B}$ with the same pivots $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{k}$, producing an approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{A}} \approx \boldsymbol{A}$. Then $\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}^{*} \widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{A}}$.

This result establishes the connection between the low-rank approximation of a psd matrix based on the pivoted Cholesky decomposition and the low-rank approximation of a general, rectangular matrix by the column-pivoted QR decomposition. In particular, any pivot selection strategy for Cholesky decomposition (i.e., random pivoting) has an analog for QR decomposition and visa versa.

The analog of RPCholesky is the randomly pivoted QR algorithm, which was introduced by Deshpande, Vempala, Rademacher, and Wang $[9,10]$ under the name "adaptive sampling". See Algorithm 5.1 for randomly pivoted QR pseudocode. As with RPCholesky, randomly pivoted QR can be extended using block and accelerated variants; see [4] for block randomly pivoted QR pseudocode and see Algorithm 5.2 for accelerated randomly pivoted QR pseudocode. Note that Algorithm 5.2 uses a

Algorithm 5.2 Accelerated randomly pivoted QR
Input: Matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times N}$; block size $b$; number of rounds $t$
Output: Matrices $\boldsymbol{Q} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times k}, \boldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times k}$ defining $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{B}}=\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{F}^{*}$; pivot set S
Initialize $\boldsymbol{Q} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{M \times 0}, \boldsymbol{F} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{N \times 0}, \mathrm{~S} \leftarrow \emptyset$, and $\boldsymbol{u} \leftarrow \operatorname{SquaredColumnNorms}(\boldsymbol{B})$ for $i=0$ to $t-1$ do

Step 1: Propose a block of pivots
Sample $s_{i b+1}^{\prime}, \ldots, s_{(i+1) b}^{\text {id }} \boldsymbol{u}$ and set $\mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime} \leftarrow\left\{s_{i b+1}^{\prime}, \ldots, s_{(i+1) b}^{\prime}\right\}$
Step 2: Rejection sampling
$\boldsymbol{C} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{B}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}_{i}^{\prime}\right)-\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{F}\left(\mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)^{*}$
$\mathrm{S}_{i} \leftarrow$ ReJeCTIONSAMPLESubmatrix $\left(\mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{C}^{*} \boldsymbol{C}\right) \quad \triangleright$ Discard second output $\mathrm{S} \leftarrow \mathrm{S} \cup \mathrm{S}_{i} \quad \triangleright$ Update pivots

Step 3: Update low-rank approximation and proposal distribution
$\boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{B}\left(:, \mathrm{~S}_{i}\right)-\boldsymbol{Q} \boldsymbol{F}\left(\mathrm{S}_{i}, \cdot\right)^{*}$
$\boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp}-\boldsymbol{Q}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{*} \boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp}\right) \quad \triangleright$ Extra step of Gram-Schmidt, for stability
$\boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp} \leftarrow \operatorname{Orth}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp}\right) \quad \triangleright$ Orthonormalize columns
$\boldsymbol{Q} \leftarrow\left[\begin{array}{ll}\boldsymbol{Q} & \boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp}\end{array}\right]$
$\boldsymbol{G} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{B}^{*} \boldsymbol{Q}_{\perp}$
$\boldsymbol{F} \leftarrow\left[\begin{array}{ll}\boldsymbol{F} & \boldsymbol{G}\end{array}\right]$
$\boldsymbol{u} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{u}-\operatorname{SQUAREDROWNORMS}(\boldsymbol{G}) \quad \triangleright$ Update diagonal
$\boldsymbol{u} \leftarrow \max \{\boldsymbol{u}, \mathbf{0}\} \quad \triangleright$ Helpful in floating point arithmetic
end for
block Gram-Schmidt procedure to perform orthogonalization, which employs two orthogonalization steps for improved stability [19]. A different, even more numerically stable approach uses Householder reflectors instead [20, Ch. 5].

Due to the connection between QR and Cholesky (Proposition 5.1), theoretical results for block and accelerated RPCholesky immediately extend to their QR analogs:

Corollary 5.2 (Sufficient iterations for accelerated and block randomly pivoted QR). Consider a rectangular matrix $\boldsymbol{B} \in \mathbb{C}^{M \times N}$, and let $\boldsymbol{B}^{(t)}$ denote the random residual after applying $t$ rounds of accelerated randomly pivoted $Q R$ or block randomly pivoted $Q R$ with a block size $b \geq 1$. Then,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{B}^{(t)}\right\|_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} \leq(1+\varepsilon) \cdot \sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \sigma_{i}(\boldsymbol{B})^{2}
$$

as soon as

$$
t b \geq \frac{r}{\varepsilon}+(r+b) \log \left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon \eta}\right), \quad \text { where } \eta=\frac{\sum_{i=r+1}^{N} \sigma_{i}(\boldsymbol{B})^{2}}{\sum_{i=1}^{r} \sigma_{i}(\boldsymbol{B})^{2}}
$$

Accelerated randomly pivoted QR is a new algorithm, while block randomly pivoted QR was introduced and analyzed in [9, Thm. 1.2]. This earlier analysis has the large block size limitation that is discussed in section 4.

Appendix A. Why blocking? Figures 1 to 3 demonstrate the empirical speed-ups of algorithms that simultaneously process large blocks of columns from kernel matrices. Subsection 1.2 has discussed one reason for this speed-up, due to data movement. This appendix describes two additional reasons why blocked (kernel) matrix algorithms can be faster: the fast Euclidean distances trick (Appendix A.1) and matrix-matrix operations (Appendix A.2).
A.1. The fast Euclidean distances trick. The fast Euclidean distances trick is a method for evaluating kernel matrix entries that take the special form

$$
\kappa\left(\boldsymbol{x}_{i}, \boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right)=\phi\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{i}-\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right\|\right) \quad \text { for } i \in \mathrm{S}_{1}, j \in \mathrm{~S}_{2}
$$

where $\phi: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a univariate function. The trick relies on decomposing the square Euclidean distance into three summands:

$$
\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{i}-\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right\|^{2}=\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\|^{2}-2 \operatorname{Re}\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{*} \boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right\}+\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right\|^{2}
$$

It takes just $\mathcal{O}\left(d\left|\mathrm{~S}_{1}\right|+d\left|\mathrm{~S}_{2}\right|\right)$ operations to compute the square norms $\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\right\|^{2}$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{x}_{j}\right\|^{2}$ for each $i \in \mathrm{~S}_{1}$ and $j \in \mathrm{~S}_{2}$. Meanwhile, the inner products $\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{*} \boldsymbol{x}_{j}$ can be obtained from the entries of the inner product matrix

$$
\boldsymbol{X}\left(: \mathrm{S}_{1}\right)^{*} \boldsymbol{X}\left(: \mathrm{S}_{2}\right) \quad \text { where } \quad \boldsymbol{X}=\left[\begin{array}{lll}
\boldsymbol{x}_{1} & \cdots & \boldsymbol{x}_{N}
\end{array}\right]
$$

Computing the inner product matrix requires $\mathcal{O}\left(d\left|\mathrm{~S}_{1}\right|\left|\mathrm{S}_{2}\right|\right)$ operations using a single matrix-matrix, a highly optimized operation on modern computers [13, Ch. 20.1]. The fast Euclidean distances trick explains why generating columns can be $10 \times$ faster for a high-dimensional Gaussian kernel (Figure 1, left) than an $\ell_{1}$ Laplace kernel (Figure 1, right).

As a potential concern, the fast Euclidean distances trick can lead to catastrophic cancellations [22, sec. 1.7] in floating point arithmetic when two points $\boldsymbol{x}_{i}$ and $\boldsymbol{x}_{j}$ are close. Catastrophic cancellations sometimes produce inaccurate results for block RPCholesky, even after adding a multiple of the machine precision to the diagonal of the target matrix to promote stability. In contrast, accelerated RPCholesky avoids catastrophic cancellations by rejecting the small diagonal values as pivots. The opportunity to use the fast Euclidean distances trick without catastrophic cancellations is a major advantage of accelerated RPCholesky. Nonetheless, to promote a simple comparison, all the experiments involving block RPCholesky avoid the fast Euclidean distances trick; the code computes distances by subtracting $\boldsymbol{x}_{i}-\boldsymbol{x}_{j}$ and directly calculating the norm.
A.2. Matrix-matrix operations. The cost of RPCholesky-type methods can be decomposed into the cost of generating columns of the kernel matrix and the cost of processing the columns to execute the algorithm. Blocking leads to speed-ups in both steps of the algorithm. For the second step, blocking organizes the operations into efficient matrix-matrix operations. Accelerated RPCholesky takes advantage of these optimized operations for an improved runtime. Simple RPCholesky, by contrast, uses only vector-vector and matrix-vector operations, which are slower.

Appendix B. Deferred proofs from section 4. This section contains deferred proofs from section 4.

Proof of Lemma 4.6. The proof is based on a series of direct calculations.

Parts (a)-(b). Observe that

$$
\phi_{\alpha}(x)=\frac{\alpha}{4}-\frac{1}{\alpha}\left(x-\frac{\alpha}{2}\right)^{2}
$$

is a concave quadratic which is uniformly bounded by $\frac{\alpha}{4}$. This immediately establishes part (a) and part (b) in the case $b=1$. Next assume part (b) is valid for some $b \geq 1$ and assume $x \leq x^{\prime} \leq \alpha / 2$. By the boundedness property (a), $\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x) \leq \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \leq \alpha / 4$. Since $x \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}(x)$ is non-decreasing over the range $\left[0, \frac{\alpha}{2}\right]$, it follows:

$$
\phi_{\alpha}^{(b+1)}(x)=\phi_{\alpha}\left(\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)\right) \leq \phi_{\alpha}\left(\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right)=\phi_{\alpha}^{(b+1)}\left(x^{\prime}\right)
$$

which establishes part (b) by induction.
Part (c). Calculate

$$
\phi_{\beta \cdot \alpha}(\beta \cdot x)=\beta x-\frac{\beta}{\alpha} x^{2}=\beta\left[x-\frac{x^{2}}{\alpha}\right]=\beta \cdot \phi_{\alpha}(x)
$$

which confirms part (c) when $b=1$. Homogeneity for $b \geq 1$ follows by induction.
Part (d). The quadratic representation (B.1) shows that $\phi_{1}$ is concave. Assume that $\phi_{1}^{(b)}$ is concave for some $b \geq 1$. Then, calculate for $\theta \in(0,1)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta \phi_{1}^{(b+1)}(x)+(1-\theta) \phi_{1}^{(b+1)}(y) & =\theta \phi_{1}\left(\phi_{1}^{(b)}(x)\right)+(1-\theta) \phi_{1}\left(\phi_{1}^{(b)}(y)\right) \\
& \leq \phi_{1}\left(\theta \phi_{1}^{(b)}(x)+(1-\theta) \phi_{1}^{(b)}(y)\right) \\
& \leq \phi_{1}\left(\phi_{1}^{(b)}(\theta x+(1-\theta) y)\right)=\phi_{1}^{(b+1)}(\theta x+(1-\theta) y)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first inequality is concavity of $\phi_{1}$, and the second inequality is concavity of $\phi_{1}^{(b)}$ and parts (a)-(b). Conclude by induction that $\phi_{1}^{(b)}$ is concave for each $b \geq 1$.

The next step is to establish joint concavity of $(x, \alpha) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)$. For any $\theta \in(0,1)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta \phi_{\alpha_{1}}^{(b)}\left(x_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \phi_{\alpha_{2}}^{(b)}\left(x_{2}\right) & =\theta \alpha_{1} \phi_{1}^{(b)}\left(\frac{x_{1}}{\alpha_{1}}\right)+(1-\theta) \alpha_{2} \phi_{1}^{(b)}\left(\frac{x_{2}}{\alpha_{2}}\right) \\
& \leq\left[\theta \alpha_{1}+(1-\theta) \alpha_{2}\right] \phi_{1}^{(b)}\left(\frac{\theta x_{1}+(1-\theta) x_{2}}{\theta \alpha_{1}+(1-\theta) \alpha_{2}}\right) \\
& =\phi_{\theta \alpha_{1}+(1-\theta) \alpha_{2}}^{(b)}\left(\theta x_{1}+(1-\theta) x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first equality is part (c), and the inequality is the concavity of $\phi_{1}^{(b)}$. Part (d) is proven.

Part (e). Calculate

$$
\phi_{\alpha}(x)=x-\frac{x^{2}}{\alpha} \leq x-\frac{x^{2}}{x+\alpha}=\frac{\alpha x}{x+\alpha}=\frac{1}{\alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}}
$$

which confirms part (e) in the case $b=1$. Next assume part (e) holds for some value $b \geq 1$. Then using the monotonicity property (b),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{\alpha}^{(b+1)}(x) & =\phi_{\alpha}\left(\phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)\right) \\
& \leq \phi_{\alpha}\left(\frac{1}{b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}}\right)=\frac{1}{b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}}-\frac{1}{\left(b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}\right)\left(b+\alpha x^{-1}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}}-\frac{1}{\left(b \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}\right)\left(b+1+\alpha x^{-1}\right)}=\frac{1}{(b+1) \alpha^{-1}+x^{-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, part (e) holds by induction.

Proof of Lemma 4.7. The proof is based on a series of direct calculations.
Part (a). Assume $\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1} \preceq \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}$. Use the positive homogeneity and concavity of $(x, \alpha) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)$ (Lemma 4.6c-d) to calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2} \phi_{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)}^{(b)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) & \preceq \frac{1}{2} \phi_{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)}^{(b)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \phi_{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}-\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)}^{(b)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}-\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) \\
& \preceq \phi_{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)}^{(b)}\left(\frac{1}{2} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \phi_{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)}^{(b)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Equivalently, $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)$. Iterating this property establishes part (a).
Part (b). Use the concavity of $(x, \alpha) \mapsto \phi_{\alpha}^{(b)}(x)$ (Lemma 4.6d) to conclude:

$$
\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) \quad \text { for } \theta \in(0,1)
$$

This confirms part (b) in the case $t=1$. Next assume part (b) holds for $t \geq 1$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right) & =\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \preceq \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}\left(\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)\right) \\
& =\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t+1)}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first inequality is the concavity of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}$, and the second inequality is the concavity of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{b}^{(t)}$ and the monotonicity property (a). Therefore, by induction, part (b) holds for $t \geq 1$.

Part (c). Calculate

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\theta \boldsymbol{A}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)-\theta \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)-(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{\theta \boldsymbol{A}_{1}^{2}}{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)}+\frac{(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{A}_{2}^{2}}{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)}-\frac{\left[\theta \boldsymbol{A}_{1}+(1-\theta) \boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right]^{2}}{\theta \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)} \\
& =\frac{\theta(1-\theta) \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right) \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)}{\theta \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)+(1-\theta) \operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)}\left[\frac{\boldsymbol{A}_{1}}{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right)}-\frac{\boldsymbol{A}_{2}}{\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{2}\right)}\right]^{2} \succeq \mathbf{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

This establishes the concavity of $\boldsymbol{\Phi}_{1}$ over all psd matrices.
Appendix C. Robust blockwise random pivoting. The robust blockwise random pivoting (RBRP) method was introduced by Dong, Chen, Martinsson, and Pearce to improve the performance of block randomly pivoted QR [12]. Similar to accelerated randomly pivoted QR, each round of RBRP begins by generating a block of proposed pivots $\mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}=\left\{s_{i b+1}^{\prime}, \ldots, s_{i+1 j b}^{\prime}\right\}$. Then RBRP chooses a subset of the pivots by a deterministic, greedy method. In detail, let $\boldsymbol{G}$ denote the residual submatrix with columns indexed by $\mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}$ :

$$
\boldsymbol{G}=\boldsymbol{B}\left(:, \mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{B}}\left(:, \mathrm{S}_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

RBRP applies a partial QR decomposition to $\boldsymbol{G}$ using greedy column pivoting, stopping when the squared Frobenius norm of $\boldsymbol{G}$ has been reduced by a factor $b$. RBRP then accepts the pivots chosen before the tolerance is met and rejects all others.

RBRP can be extended to psd low-rank approximation, resulting in a robust block randomly pivoted Cholesky method. A comparison of RBRP Cholesky, block RPCholesky, and accelerated RPCholesky appears in Table 3. Both accelerated

![table_2](table_2)

Table 3: Runtime and relative error for rank-1000 approximation of the smile example from Figure 2 with block size $b=120$. Here the mean and standard deviation are computed empirically over 100 independent trials.

RPCholesky and RBRP Cholesky achieve dramatically lower trace error than standard block RPCholesky on this example, demonstrating that both methods are effective at filtering redundant columns. This example does suggest a few preliminary reasons to (slightly) prefer accelerated RPCholesky over RBRP Cholesky, though. First, RBRP Cholesky has $1.4 \times$ higher trace error than accelerated RPCholesky on this example, and the error of the output is more variable for RBRP Cholesky. Second, RBRP Cholesky is slightly slower than accelerated RPCholesky in our implementation. Finally, rigorous error bounds are known for accelerated RPCholesky (and QR), but not known for RBRP methods. Notwithstanding these difference, RBRP methods and accelerated RPCholesky/QR both appear to be fast and accurate in practice, and both methods significantly out-compete standard block RPCholesky/QR.

sections.text:
# Algorithm D. 1 RPCholesky 

Input: Psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$; approximation rank $k$
Output: Matrix $\boldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times k}$ defining low-rank approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{A}}=\boldsymbol{F} \boldsymbol{F}^{*}$; pivot set S Initialize $\boldsymbol{F} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{N \times k}$ and $\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \operatorname{diag} \boldsymbol{A}$
for $i=1$ to $k$ do
Sample pivot $s \sim \boldsymbol{d} / \sum_{j} d_{j}$
Induct new pivot $\mathrm{S} \leftarrow \mathrm{S} \cup\{s\}$
$\boldsymbol{g} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{A}(:, s)-\boldsymbol{F}(:, 1: i-1) \boldsymbol{F}(s, 1: i-1)^{*}$
$\boldsymbol{F}(:, i) \leftarrow \boldsymbol{g} / \sqrt{g_{s}}$
$\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{d}-|\boldsymbol{F}(:, i)|^{2}$
end for

# Algorithm D. 2 Block RPCholesky 

Input: Psd matrix $\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times N}$; block size $b$; number of rounds $\underline{t}$
Output: Matrix $\boldsymbol{F} \in \mathbb{C}^{N \times b t}$ defining low-rank approximation $\widehat{\boldsymbol{A}}=\boldsymbol{F} \boldsymbol{F}^{*}$; pivot set S Initialize $\boldsymbol{F} \leftarrow \mathbf{0}_{N \times b k}, \mathrm{~S} \leftarrow \emptyset$, and $\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \operatorname{diag} \boldsymbol{A}$
for $i=0$ to $t-1$ do
Sample $s_{i b+1}, \ldots, s_{i b+b} \stackrel{\text { iid }}{\sim} \boldsymbol{d} / \sum_{j} d_{j}$
$\mathrm{S}^{\prime} \leftarrow \operatorname{UniqUE}\left(\left\{s_{i b+1}, \ldots, s_{i b+T}\right\}\right)$
$\mathrm{S} \leftarrow \mathrm{S} \cup \mathrm{S}^{\prime}$
$\boldsymbol{G} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{A}\left(:, \mathrm{S}^{\prime}\right)-\boldsymbol{F}(:, 1: i T) \boldsymbol{F}\left(\mathrm{S}^{\prime}, 1: i T\right)^{*}$
$\boldsymbol{R} \leftarrow \operatorname{Chol}\left(\boldsymbol{G}\left(\mathrm{S}^{\prime},:\right)\right)$
$\boldsymbol{F}(:, i b+1: i b+\left|\mathrm{S}^{\prime}\right|) \leftarrow \boldsymbol{G} \boldsymbol{R}^{-1}$
$\boldsymbol{d} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{d}-\operatorname{SQUAREDROWNORMS}(\boldsymbol{F}(:, i b+1: i b+b))$
end for
Remove zero columns from $\boldsymbol{F}$

abstract:
Randomly pivoted Cholesky (RPCholesky) is an algorithm for constructing a
low-rank approximation of a positive-semidefinite matrix using a small number
of columns. This paper develops an accelerated version of RPCholesky that
employs block matrix computations and rejection sampling to efficiently
simulate the execution of the original algorithm. For the task of approximating
a kernel matrix, the accelerated algorithm can run over $40\times$ faster. The
paper contains implementation details, theoretical guarantees, experiments on
benchmark data sets, and an application to computational chemistry.
